definitions.definition: the part of the face that sticks out above the mouth, used for breathing and smelling things
definitions.labels: (figurative)(informal)(formal)(British English)(British English)(disapproving)(both informal, often disapproving)(informal, disapproving)

examples.text: She had dark eyes and a long narrow nose.
He broke his nose in the fight.
She wrinkled her nose in disgust.
He pressed his nose up against the window.
Try to breathe through your nose.
He **blew his nose** *(= cleared it by blowing strongly into a )*.
a **blocked/runny nose**
Stop **picking your nose**! *(= removing dirt from it with your finger)*
He **held his nose** as he passed the stinking dustbins.
He held his nose and voted for the bill anyway.
He pushed his glasses up **the bridge of his nose** *(= the hard part near the top)*.
Cats have very sensitive noses and rely heavily on scent markings.
Charlie pressed his nose against the window.
He stuck his bulbous red nose back into his pint of beer.
He tapped his nose in a knowing gesture.
His nose wrinkled with distaste.
I had to wear a black moustache and false nose for the role.
She dressed up as a clown with a white face and red nose.
She walked with her shoulders back and her nose pointing skyward.
She was weeping loudly and her nose was running.
She wrinkled her nose as if she had just smelled a bad smell.
The boy sat there with his finger up his nose.
The dog pushed its wet nose into my palm.
The sharp nose and thin lips gave his face a very harsh look.
a child with a runny nose

phrases: with your nose in the air
look down your nose at somebody

definitions.definition: having the type of nose mentioned

examples.text: red-nosed
large-nosed

definitions.definition: the front part of a plane, spacecraft, etc.

examples.text: Heat detectors are fitted in the nose of the missile.
He pushed the nose down for the final approach.
The plane's nose dipped as it started descending towards the runway.

definitions.definition: a special ability for finding or recognizing something

examples.text: As a journalist, she has always had a nose for a good story.

definitions.definition: a sense of smell

examples.text: a dog with a good nose
Good noses can always smell a fight brewing.

definitions.definition: a smell that is characteristic of a particular wine

examples.text: This Cote de Beaune has a good nose, with apricot and raisin aromas.

definitions.definition: by only a small amount (used mostly when talking about horse racing)

examples.text: He lost his first race by a nose but won the next three.
Glen's Diamond was declared the winner by a nose from the 11–4 favourite.

definitions.definition: to do something when you are angry that is meant to harm somebody else but that also harms you
to be guided by your sense of smell
to go straight forward

examples.text: The garage is a mile ahead up the hill—just follow your nose.

definitions.definition: to act according to what seems right or reasonable, rather than following any particular rules
if you say that people have their noses in the trough, you mean that they are trying to get a lot of money for themselves
to annoy somebody
to defeat somebody

examples.text: We have to give him a bloody nose in the election.
Voters gave the government a bloody nose in the local elections.

definitions.definition: to be reading

examples.text: She always has her nose in a book.

definitions.definition: to be reading something and giving it all your attention

examples.text: Peter always has his nose in a book.

definitions.definition: to look around a place; to look for something in a place

examples.text: I’ll have a nose round and see what I can find.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody is not upset or annoyed about something because it does not affect them in a bad way
to avoid doing anything wrong or illegal

examples.text: Since leaving prison, he's managed to keep his nose clean.

definitions.definition: to not become involved in things that should not really involve you
to work hard for a long period of time without stopping
to make somebody do everything you want; to control somebody completely
to behave in a way that suggests that you think that you are better than somebody or that something is not good enough for you

examples.text: People who live in that area tend to look down their noses at their poorer neighbours.
They tend to look down their noses at people who drive small cars.

definitions.definition: if cars, etc. are nose to tail, they are moving slowly in a long line with little space between them

examples.text: The traffic was nose to tail for miles.

definitions.definition: exactly

examples.text: The budget should hit the $136 billion target on the nose.

definitions.definition: to pay too much money for something
very obvious
to try to become involved in something that should not involve you

examples.text: He’s always poking his nose into other people’s business.

definitions.definition: a polite way to say that somebody goes to the toilet

examples.text: I'm just going to powder my nose.

definitions.definition: to upset or annoy somebody, especially by not giving them enough attention
to keep reminding somebody in an unkind way of their past mistakes
to make a rude sign with your thumb on your nose; to show that you have no respect for somebody/something

examples.text: The company just thumbs its nose at the legislation on pollution.
They thumb their noses at all of our traditions.

definitions.definition: to refuse something, especially because you do not think that it is good enough for you

examples.text: The children turn up their noses at almost everything I cook.

definitions.definition: if something is under somebody’s nose, it is very close to them but they cannot see it

examples.text: I searched everywhere for the letter and it was under my nose all the time!

definitions.definition: if something happens under somebody’s nose, they do not notice it even though it is not being done secretly

examples.text: The police didn't know the drugs ring was operating right under their noses.

definitions.definition: in a way that is not friendly and suggests that you think that you are better than other people

examples.text: She walked in with her nose in the air, ignoring everyone.

wordOrigin: Old English nosu, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch neus, and more remotely to German Nase, Latin nasus, and Sanskrit nāsā.
